Award.AbstractNarration:
Number theory is one of the oldest branches of mathematics and has a very rich history. Modern number theorists are interested in the field of algebraic numbers (numbers that satisfy a polynomial equation with rational coefficients) and its group of symmetries (which is an example of a Galois group). The conjectures of Langlands and Fontaine-Mazur then predict that representations of this group are intimately related to objects from distinct branches of mathematics such as representation theory, analysis and algebraic geometry. Progress on these conjectures has led to some spectacular results such as Wiles' proof of Fermat's Last Theorem and has been a driving force for much development in neighboring fields. Objects of fundamental interest in this theory, such as elliptic curves, play a large role in cryptography and internet security.

This project is concerned with the correspondence, predicted by Langlands and Fontaine-Mazur, between Galois representations and automorphic representations. This correspondence is still largely conjectural but there has been much progress in recent years. The proof of the Shimura-Taniyama conjecture has been considerably generalized to rather general potential automorphy theorems that apply to Galois representations of arbitrary dimension. Such results have led, for example, to a proof of the Sato-Tate conjecture. On the other hand, these results have the restriction that they apply only to Galois representations with distinct Hodge-Tate weights. This restriction rules out some well known examples of Galois representations such as Artin representations and the Tate modules of abelian varieties of dimension greater than one. The principal goal of this project is to develop modularity results that apply to Galois representations with repeated Hodge-Tate weights.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to develop new methods for proving
"modularity" of Galois representations. In modern number theory, the
Langlands program predicts a link between number theoretic objects
such as Galois representations or elliptic curves and analytic objects
such as modular forms or automorphic representations. To say that a
Galois representation is "modular" means that one can find a modular
form that "matches" the Galois representation in a fundamental way.

Andrew Wiles and Richard Taylor proved the first modularity theorem as
part of Wiles' proof of Fermat's Last Theorem: they showed that a
large class of elliptic curves are modular. Their original method was
generalized by many mathematicians and led to many significant
developments in the field. For example, the proofs of Serre's
modularity conjecture and the Sato--Tate conjecture make heavy use of
modularity results.

Nonetheless, it was the case that many "simple" classes of Galois
representations fell outside the scope of the Taylor--Wiles
method. Such examples include the case of Galois representations of
finite image or Galois representations corresponding to "abelian
surfaces" (abelian surfaces are natural generalizations of elliptic
curves). For certain of these excluded cases, mathematicians found
alternative methods to attack the problem but a general approach was missing.

The main outcome of this project is joint work with Frank
Calegari that shows how to modify the Taylor--Wiles method in order
to treat many of these missing cases. (There are still some
"non-cohomological" cases which are even more mysterious and for which
no possible approach is currently known.) This should open the door to
proving modularity of a wide class of interesting Galois
representations (work in progress of the PI with Calegari).

In addition to the above, another major outcome of this project was a
joint work of the PI with Ana Caraiani, Matthew Emerton, Toby Gee,
Vytautas Paskunas and Sug-Woo Shin. In this work, we construct a
candidate for the p-adic local Langlands correspondence. Finding a
p-adic local Langlands correspondence that goes beyond the case of
GL(2) has so far proved elusive. Our work represents a novel approach
to the problem that uses global methods (in particular, the
Taylor--Wiles method).

Over the course of the project, the PI was engaged in a number of
educational programs for younger students. These include:
- a course for high school students on the p-adic Riemann zeta function taught by the PI at the PROMYS program (Boston University)
- courses for graduate students on modularity lifting at the Arizona Winter School (University of Arizona) and IISER (Pune, India).
